The office space is terrible, unprofessional, like a call center, and outdated, but the CEO created a new wing as an auditorium for members to meet every so often?? There is no professional development here at all, PD is not even emphasized by your manager! They don't even do performance reviews! I mean seriously how pathetic is that?! Things toil and boil and never get done, no accountability, and endless meetings with no purpose. The other major nonprofit rivals destroy Catholic Charities at all levels. This place is dying for new leadership, and some people need to be shown the door. This company is all about process office politics and personalities and not any sort of meaningful output.

review_title: Horrible place to work if your non Latinx , have higher education and common sense
job_title: Resident Attendant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are no pros to working at Good Shepherd Center for Homeless women and children. Maybe to day you git some experience working I'm homeless services maybe. I'm too embarrassed to say I worked there.
cons:
Where do I begin? Shady practices. Even lawyers have said so. Also there are/ have been lawsuits against gsc due to the associate director's craziness and discriminatory practices. If you're an uneducated, iliiterate Latinx who has no previous work experience, poor social skills and work habits, come to with when you feel like it, come to work like you're going to a club or you were just cleaning the garage they've got a position for you. If you're educated - high school would be nice but I'm talking higher education from higher tired universities with at least a Bachelor's degree move along. It's not worth your stress levels.
Thscwomen and ger minions create a toxic work environment pitting employees against each other, passive aggressive moves like reducing one's hours by hiring more people for the position so you've got nothing. The lying, illegal hiring and firing practices - you have to sign a form saying you will NOT take breaks or a lunch otherwise you don't get the RA position yet you watch everyone else in other positions take a lunch. The AD micro manages, lies, has her own agenda. 
The resident attendant position is a joke and you are treated subhuman and as a punching bag for the female residents who come through. Many, if not all have substance abuse, trauma and or co occurring mental illness so they act out a lot. This is the reason they are homeless in the first place. You are exoected to handke the position like an educated clinician and when you don't marks against you unless you have more melanin in your skin. You are untouchable no matter how bad you are at your job. There's no care for you the employee nor are you believed or backed up when these women do something to break the rules or try to physically hurt you regardless if it's on camera. No one's read the scholarship on trauma informed care at this place.

job_title: Family Service Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: The people I worked with really loved their job, and they truly impacted the lives of those they worked with. These are not folks in the offices, but the folks working at the ground level, working directly with people in need.
cons: The management was not set-up for the success of those I worked with. I worked at a homeless shelter, and the amount of rules and restrictions imposed on the people there made it simply a prison until they were forced to leave (it is a day-time only shelter). Because of the short staffing, there simply wasn't enough attention focused on everyone, which isn't the fault of my coworkers but that of planning this facility. There could have been so much more invested into the place in terms of creating plans to better the lives of those in the shelter, and yet it was pretty much designed to be relief from homelessness for a mere 7 hours until they were forced to leave. A better emphasis on resource allocation would have been great, especially for the family department.  All of my ideas for improvement were shot down by management, which would have made my life and the lives of the people I worked with better, however.

pros: I've worked in several localities and they are very different each.  Coworkers are supportive of each other.  You can bet that all are there to help others rather than themselves although they may have very contrasting ways of thinking they are accomplishing that goal.  One can have a great variety of experiences or none depending on the office structure.  Starting out I managed an office with a great young staff and lots of travel and perks.  Three years later at a different location I had no perks and was stuck in a sparse office with a bunch of old horrible morons and a management that couldn't find their way out of an open box.  One can move up down or laterally very quickly.
cons: Coworkers can be self righteous, especially if they are ones who come from money and feel like they are doing the world a favor.  They do not understand poverty and tend to feel sorry for clients, which is derogatory I believe.  They are in the vast minority but negatively effect the whole company.  Locations will have a strong tendency to resist change even if they are very unsuccessful.  This is probably because they are not trained to make a company successful, being a non-profit.

review_title: This is a place for a person with ambition to help people and not make money!
pros: It is a relaxed work environment where they still trust in their employees to do what is necessary for each of their programs to succeed.  Since, this is a non-profit organization the little perks given like a long lunch and only working 7.5 hours a day makes it ok to not have constant bonuses.  The yearly bonus for Christmas is a nice a perk if and when they have the funds.  I recommend Catholic Charities as a place to work for if you don't care to succeed in other ways other than helping people.  If you don't care about money and the work you do is because you really want to help than this is the place for you.
cons: Underpaid staff, not much of employee appreciation, such as a floating holiday for outstanding work.  There is really no recognition program for those that go above and beyond the call of duty other than for volunteers.

with that, they expect you to go beyond your limits. 

Favoritism

You feel like you are working in a factory rather than actually helping the client's. It is all about numbers and collecting information for statistical purposes for the department of aging, so you do feel a bit intrusive asking a ton of personal questions. Some client's even feel insulted by some of the questions you HAVE to ask. 

You feel the burn out quickly

It truly depends under which agency you are working for.  When I worked in disaster case management under catholic charities, it was a different story.

review_title: Senior Management does well, mid and lower level staff struggle.
pros: The management and the staff really care about the mission of the organization. The staff are caring people as a whole. The current leadership (2010+) are bright, progressive individuals looking to steer the organization as effectively as possible.
cons: The current leadership team, both administrative, development, and program leadership have been promoted, some within a couple of years of employment. No harm no foul. However, opportunity for many staff at mid and lower levels of the organization is very limited. Leaves one with a sense of management takes care of their own, but what is good for the goose is not good for the gander.  Although management sends out an employee survey, evidence of resolution of issues is not forthcoming. A large swath of the lower and mid tier staff cite 'employee recognition' as a chief complaint. Little is done.

pros:
- mission-driven organization that truly does care about its clients and making the world around it a better place.  
- good amount of life/work balance.
cons:
- The hiearchy of the organization (and the Church) is imposing and despite the promise that the employee has a chance to share his/her idea, that is merely an illusion.
- the HR and IT departments and inflexible and do not assist employees satisfactorily.
- many managers are selfish and oftentimes inflexible. The mission of Catholic Charities becomes only a nice afterthought.

review_title: It was the most gratifying chaos I've ever experienced the clientele was so awesome and rewarding
pros: Play until there is awesome they are so appreciative of everything that you do for them for the most part staff has been very helpful and is very well educated
cons: Staff is all new currently that's doing orientation and everybody is just getting used to their own rules much less training anybody else in so it can be kind of trying at times because you're not sure exactly what you're doing or what should you should be doing

pros: You are able gain great knowledge and experience, make friends. Other program staff and managers are helpful and friendly.
cons: Inside communication is bad. Management explains "top down" communication - but nothing actually gets communicated past same circle of management directors, CEO, HR. Lots of staff are using this job as temp. one while waiting on another more permanent one.

review_title: Supervise children under age and help them know computer knowledge.
job_title: Account Receivable in San Jose, CA
pros: The best reason I like to work is because accounting is my field and the company is familiar to me
cons: Training would be the best beginning for any individual to place in a job market even though he/she knows about the job. Every company has its own policy to follow. That's why it is necessary to train people so that the person has to grow fast in knowledge as well as the company benefited etc

pros: Horrible place to work.  Supervisor was mean and verbally abusive to clients.  No one was there to help clients improve their lives and you can pretty much do anything you want all shift without having to work at all.
cons: The conditions working there were unhealthy on many levels.  The Catholic Church is far too involved in the treatment of clients who are in no way affiliated with this religion.  Clients and staff are treated very poorly and borderline illegal.  Worst job by far I have ever had.

review_title: Great mission and goals but not much opportunity for advancement
pros: The mission of the nonprofit is good - they have good intentions and a lot of programs that are intended to help community members who are most in need.
cons: There are some managerial issues that prevent the realization of some of the ultimate aims of the organization, not much opportunity for movement or advancement in the company.

review_title: Personally satisfying organization for the idealist
pros: Benefits are decent and vacation, personal day, holy/holiday time off is extremely generous. Wide network of services offered within the agency gives you the capacity to make a dramatic impact on client's lives.
cons: Matrix management structure is enough to give you a migraine. Many in management are disconnected from the difficulty of the work that we do.

review_title: Good position for people who love helping others.
job_title: Group Life Worker in Washington, DC
pros: Catholic Community Services is a great non-profit organization that gives back to the community and helps a range of individuals. Leave work knowing that you are making a difference. Pretty flexible hours to work. Good starting pay compared to other related companies. Great jog during school and post graduation.
cons: I felt that there was really no room to growth in my position. Felt like the leadership could have been better and more structured. No bonuses for exceptional work. No budget for extracurricular activities with the youth, so be prepared to do a lot of sitting around or going to the park.

pros: Serving clients is the best and most rewarding part for any case manager in the field
cons: This organization hires people with criminal backgrounds, They have numerous people on staff convicted of heinous crimes, they also have many staff members with counterfeit college degrees. My  last month there I found that NYC grant money is being is being diverted to victims of the Catholic Church, the grant money was awarded to them for mental health programs, after becoming aware I immediately left. If notice on there staff list no african American has ever had a position in  upper management. Catholic charities is a business and I understand the practice, i just feel sorry for those unaware of these tactics

review_title: Too much turnover, too much focus on making money.
pros: Agency has multiple programs providing a variety of services in the community. There are many dedicated employees. There are opportunities to move around between programs for advancement.
cons: A lot of turnover, firing of employees, focus entirely on the money and prestige of the organization. The upper management is very out of touch with the day to day activities and responsibilities the programs have, yet very critical. They minimally fund programs and except them to be superior.

review_title: Hope House Senior Services Chore Worker. Great job for helping people
job_title: Senior Services Chore Worker in Dover, NJ
pros:
I liked feeling like my job was meaningful and really making a difference in people's lives. The holidays were off and paid. My hours were flexible and reasonable times of the day. My supervisor was great and easy to talk to. There was plenty of support and information available to help with the job.
Nice Christmas party. It was like a family.
cons: The pay was not high. I was part time and had no insurance and there was no option in my particular job for full time although there are other jobs that offer full time within Catholic Charities.

job_title: Community Support Professional in Danvers, MA
pros:
-opportunity to empower individuals with disabilities to engage the community and improve their overall quality of life
-management was very supportive  and willing to help their staff in all scenarios
-benefits are amazing
cons: It is the social work field, so the pay was not great. The position was good to supplement a second and third job. unless you are not the primary caregiver, this salary will not sustain you. At times, the job itself was very demanding and hours could be very unpredictable. Staff would often be working off the clock to complete all the necessary paperwork.

review_title: Well intentioned people, but dysfunctional internal politics and outmoded hierarchical protocols.
pros: Organization seems committed to the mission of uplifting the poor.  A high level of dedication among staff and volunteers.  Opportunity for advancement.  Flexible schedule is very good for families.  Good health care benefits.
cons: No realistic strategic fundraising plan.  Lack of understanding and respect by program and operations staff for development team knowledge, practices, and pressures.  Insufficient collaboration and cooperation between senior program staff and development, especially during program planning stages.  Destructive pettiness and office politics.

pros: The causes they champion are great. They offer help to victims of violence, immigration, at risk teens, as well as help to refugees.
cons: Management is bad. High turnover and low salaries. Programs people are expected to work overtime several days a week and sometimes weekends. They will gladly do it but they get no overtime pay. Salaries for workers are stagnant and only newer hires have better salaries. Senior management seems to be a bit at a loss of how they affect their employees.

review_title: Great place to work with  great mission, doesn't pay ...
pros: CC is a great place to work if you want to work somewhere with a purpose. Their a major player in fighting Twin Cities poverty, they do a lot of great work. But I have to say, I feel vastly underpaid for the work I do.
cons: The pay here is low, at least in my position. I know what some of the people I work with make, and they might be more valuable than me, but not THAT much more valuble.

pros: The biggest pro of working at St. Joseph's Home for Children through Catholic Charities is that several of the staff are really dedicated to the kids and the work that they do.
cons: The cons listed are specifically for St. Joseph's Home for Children and does not reflect Catholic Charities as a whole. The biggest concern of working here is the lack of safety for staff. There was constant understaffing and with the population of youth they serve, this created a physically unsafe environment for staff causing many staff to be injured. The shelter itself is not currently capable of accepting youth with severe behavioral issues but they continue to do so despite the lack of safety.

pros: St. Vincent's School for Boys offers opportunity to help children in deep need, most diverse workforce in terms of background and talent, highest level of workplace camaraderie imaginable, wonderful source of satisfaction in short and long term effects of effort.
cons: Highest level of minute to minute, hour to hour, and day to day physical and emotional stress ever encountered, high risk of exhaustion and burnout.

pros: Working to help others is a what Catholic Charities is about. Helping people through hard times, being the place to go when no one else wants to help. Seeing the light come on in a person's eyes and that smile of thanks.
cons: Low pay and not enough hours to do all the work. Being left out of the loop. No direction on how to do a job and letting just anyone work there. Need to support each employee not just those who gossip and put other down.

review_title: Interviewed and offered job but did not accept job
pros: The interview was with the head of the legal department and the two attorneys who would be overseeing me as the legal assistant. All three were very nice and welcoming. They asked behavioral based questions one at a time. They asked if I had any questions afterwards and finished the interview by explaining their work culture and benefits package to me. They were all very kind and respectful. It appears that they have a very wonderful work environment there.
cons: I would have loved to work there had the pay/offer not been so low.

review_title: Catholic Charities of Baltimore treats employees poorly.
pros: Non profit Work. free coffee
cons: Low Pay, stingy benefits, no career advancement, Management and HR do not care for employees,

review_title: Fair working conditions for the Community Services division.
job_title: Case Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Medical Benefits and retirement plan.  CEH credits.  Good time off compensations.  Many different services for the public within the organization.  Mortgage counseling for the HRC department good and reliable.
cons: Personal growth and morale low due to lack of management for the Social Services department within the Community Services area and lack of funding.  Low wages for HRC staff.

review_title: My experience is very enlightening, never a dull moment with my clients
job_title: Home Health Aide in Chicago, IL
pros: I enjoy this job tremendously because I get to meet interesting clients. Even though they are senior citizens they can be very funny and full of history.
cons: The only cons is knowing that some of them suffer greatly from pain and loneliness everyday.. Sometimes more than anything else all they want is some company, which I am always happy to oblige.

review_title: I felt as if everyone was out for themselves and their was little true "team work".
pros: I gained some valuable insights into human nature and the psychological aspects of abuse victim treatment. This experience gave me a better understanding of what caregivers are capable of.
cons: The employee union was a farce with no teeth or power, and yet individuals were expected to pay dues into it whether or not they were members.

pros: There are good clients with dire needs which can be met on some occasions and the direct services staff are good folk to work with.
cons: The administrative team is top heavy, bloated, arrogant, not schooled in the delivery of human services and only motivated to impress board members which have been hand picked for their gullible nature.

review_title: It's been great working at this organization.
pros: Personally i enjoy working with this organization.  It is a place where you can grow spiritually, physically and academically.  They work with you concerning schedules when in school to help you balance home, work and school.
cons: Every organization has its flaws and Catholic Charities is not an exception.

review_title: Never be content with the status quo
pros: Most of the employees are great. They are there to help people and this makes for a good work environment.
cons: Senior management needs more monitoring. The company could be much stronger if managers were given solid management training. Many employees are promoted to management without any previous management experience. This makes it difficult for these new managers to be effective; especially, people whose backgrounds are in social services not management. Resources are scarce and people have to do more with less. Management (especially Sr. Mgmt) seem stuck in the past with few long-term strategies that are grounded in the present needs of the clients and society. Little attention is paid to client's review of the programs which is a problem b/c the clients are often dissatisfied. I think employees have a hard time dealing with the client's dissatisfaction because of the lack of support from management. However, management also has a lack of support...so the chain extends upwards.

review_title: It was an ok place to work, considering it was non profit organization
pros: The job was fulfilling in the sense of helping others
cons: Pay and resources were minimal due to the fact that it is a non profit

pros:
There are locations all over the country so if you want to transfer jobs, that is possible.
There are a number of services that are provided - ranging from substance abuse, housing, aid to those who are developmentally and intellectually disabled.
There is alot of diversity within the company - you get a chance to work with people of different races, ages, ethnicity, education background, professions and so on.
cons: Working with a non-profit agency sometimes mean less pay, but if that is the main focus for a person, then he/she should not work for one.

job_title: Case Manager Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros: Great people to work with who care about serving the mentally ill.
cons:
Management obsessed with getting your "numbers", the time you spend with your clients. Because of this, workers get behind in the paperwork. You cannot do 10 hours of work in 8 hours, 
I heard that last spring 2016, that the pressure on numbers were eased, and all employees were given a raise, the first in almost 10 years.

review_title: Assisted refugees in relocation and getting jobs.
pros: Many refugees have an opportunity to start their lives over in the United States.  You feel good about what you do.
cons: Some employees goof off with long lunches or have poor attitutes towards refugees.  Not alot of supervision.  Some people work very hard and are earnest while others seem to have huge egos or just couldn't care less.

review_title: Trade off of good and bad. Not the worst place you could work, but most certainly not the best.
pros: Good benefits, time off , easier to enroll child in childcare services .  Occasional helpful resources but not much.
cons: Low pay, no raises or bonus. A big work load for a small amount of pay. Any raises were extremely minimal, but usually didn't even happen.

review_title: Has the ability to be truly awesome
job_title: Staff Clinician in Burlington Township, NJ
pros: Understands the necessity of providing enough time off to offset lower wages while trying to prevent "burn out"  especially for community staff.
cons: Compensation is on the low end of the pay scale.  Men still are paid more and are in more leadership roles. And with a female Executive Director the morale of the female staff can be low.  They rarely promote from within.

pros: Great professional network.  They are true to their mission of compassion in action.
cons: Very low salaries. Limited opportunities for promotion in some departments.

pros: The staff really love their jobs and care about the people for whom they are there.  The work is very rewarding, varied and interesting.
cons: There is much too much bureaucracy, little interest in change and progress is difficult.  There can be a lot of micro-managing from above and you do not have the freedom to grow.

review_title: Passionate people behind a strong purpose
pros: I'm a new employee, and so far I've really enjoyed going to work.  Everyone is really friendly and seem to be passionate about their work.  This is a very large organization so I'm not sure how other departments function, but the development team is simply fantastic to work with so far.
cons: I took a huge pay cut, but I think there will be ample opportunity to get into higher paying positions in the future.

review_title: A fulfilling experience that besides the monetary compensation is quite worth it.
job_title: Senior Residential Counselor in Albany, NY
pros: The relationship you will build working with the individual you serve will without a doubt have a lasting effect on you, not to mention the work environment is very relax.
cons: Due to the different type of disabilities the individual you may serve have, some day tend to be very long and stressful.

review_title: I volunteered with them as a Refugee Tutor.
job_title: Volunteer Refugee Tutor in Portland, OR
pros: I thought I was doing this in the beginning to help the children.... little did I know that I was the one getting the help.  Those children are awe inspiring.
cons: The children come from a myriad of backgrounds and experiences.  Their challenges are often reflected in their behavior.  There are times when a tutor has to have thick skin because their anger is taken out on us.

review_title: Fantastic.  An experience that would be hard to match!
pros: Get a chance to work with everything.  Your IT job experience can go from 0 to 60 in no time due to the many hats you need to wear.  Also, the intangible life/work benefits are out of this world compared to life at the corporate level, not to mention the nature of the overall work the Agency is doing.
cons: Pay.  Although this is how it is in the Non-profit world.

pros: the kids were awesome with lost of opportunities to engage with youth and build team capacity. Lots of resources and opportunities for the kids to expand and explore different interests.
cons: The site was disorganized, there is not a clear chain of command to follow. Many times workers worked beyond their contractual time but were not compensated. Very uncomfortable environment. Limited opportunities to move up on site.

review_title: Good People who help other but are not the best at running a business
job_title: Network Administrator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: great people to work with, they all share a passion to help others.  Makes work enjoyable when you know it's for a greater good.
cons: Most of the people employeed are social workers, who do not have good business sense.  They think money is free and will there will always be donation.  Running in the red for years at a time is OK to them.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Covington, KY
pros: An autonomous company when it comes to management--very lax and laid back.
cons: Agency is not always open to serving the marginalized folks in our society, not willing to accommodate some clients' schedules in the midst of a very tough economy.  Willing to harbor illegal residents and provide them services and deny those same services to US residents.

job_title: CLASSROOM SUPPORT SPECIALIST in La Crosse, WI
pros:
-Working with the disabled students is rewarding
-One or two staff members who actually care about the students

-No consequences for behavior
-Inconsistent staffing
-No one knows what they're doing
-Kids run wild

pros: Ability to serve community members in need

Poor working conditions. Employees are expected to do above average when completing tasks, and also in above average time with little to no facilities.

review_title: Working at Catholic Charities gave me the opportunity to reach out and help those that had difficulty helping themselves
pros: Seeing positive outcomes, being able to make a difference to those in need.

review_title: Fun but chaotic place to work

cons:

-Agency undergoing many changes, which also impacts staff 
-Flexibility required by staff as different grants necessitate different types of case management

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Elmont, NY

cons:
Not too many Cons at the time it can be a little flexible as younger staff in the early 20s working with older women who are in the 60s, at it feels as though they try to make you feel inferior. But once they get, use to you they are nice and understanding.
But each house has different, experiences.

pros:
I loved meeting people from all over the world. I thought the diversity of the students' background bought a amazing dynamic to the classroom.  The students were eager to learn - as an educator you could not ask for more. I love my time in the classroom.

Great central location. A wealth of great services and guidance available for the community.
cons: I was at CC for less than a year, still in the "honeymoon stage". I have no adverse experiences to mention.

review_title: High-integrity, mission-driven; asset to community organization.
pros: Serves those that others have given up on. Welcomes anyone, regardless of beliefs/ background. Services prevent homelessness. My staff and clients were a blessing. My manager deeply ethical and fair.
cons: Safety was frighteningly lax and out of date, considering criminal element in client population. New position was unrealistic. The workload and responsibility, compared to pay rate, (annual pay freezes) was unacceptable.

review_title: Good place to learn, then move on
job_title: Employment Specialist, Refugee Resettlement in Boston, MA
pros:
Entry level employees get lots of responsibility and exposure to direct service work

cons:
The pay is terrible--even in comparison with other local nonprofits
Management is incompetent and the board is very unsupportive
Poor communication creates anxiety and dysfunction

pros: As a per-Diem I was able to advance quickly from a driver to resident advisor in a halfway house. Most of the staff personal were supportive of each other, and I learned a great deal about substance and alcohol abuse in support of the residents and their needs.
cons: The greatest disappointment working as a per-Diem is the inability to provide support and counsel to residents on a daily basis.

pros: Its a job. It will pay some of the bills.
cons: Low pay, employees treated badly, terrible benefits, no career advancement. Bad managers, and HR Department that ignores everything. The company is just terrible. They claim to be a religious and social welfare organization, but they treat the employees badly. They have continued to reduce or eliminate benefits, even non monetary ones. Bad managers are ignored and HR only cares about making sure they are not sued. Health premiums are high. Retirement benefits are only earned after three years. Most dont hang around long enough for that, and annual sick days are only 6.

review_title: Stick to the mission, and dump the bullies.
pros: Most of the people are nice. They do great things for people all over this country who are in need, regardless of their personal faith. Some extraordinary people, such as the COO.
cons: Some bullies. After being hired, most of the time who cannot give your professional advice.

job_title: Substance Abuse Counseling Intern in Chicago, IL
pros: Wonderful co-workers, very relaxed environment, may be an increase in the jobs available due to the ACA enacted by the Obama administration, you can also discuss religion with clients without crossing ethical boundaries.
cons: Limited constructive criticism from my supervisor, complicated heirarchy in leadership, and low salaries due to under-funding.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Omaha, NE
pros: Extremely rewarding position, Getting to play a key role in individual's recovery process, Friendly clients and staff, Overtime avaliable

review_title: Long hours, lots of change, but great co-workers.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX

pros: Catholic Charities strongly believe in helping people be the best their can be in life, and never give up on people in all walk of life.

pros: Benefits. Holidays. Nothing else . The rest is all cons

pros: Good networking job... it helps you learn what you like and what you do not like.. you can also be linked to other services

pros: Everyone who works for Catholic Charities is passionate about helping others. Inspiring to be around like that all the time.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Fort Worth, TX

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: This agency has a great mission.  They help kids, homeless, destitute.  It is very rewarding work on a personal level.
cons: Low pay - it is a non-profit.  But you can bet the management is getting paid well!  Employment here at the worker level is a revolving door.  Their clientele is often treated better than their employees.

pros: Wonderful People to Work With (1 exception) and Wonderful Clients.

review_title: Catholic Charities is a neat company but does not take care of its employees.
job_title: Youth Counselor in Saint Cloud, MN

pros: I love working here at my current work place we are a close knit family and it makes coming to work everyday a pleasure

review_title: It is been a pleasure to work for Catholic Charities. You get  to help people of all type of  situations and problems.

review_title: Case Manager Employment Specialist Court Advocate Case Manager

job_title: Program Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Catholic Charities CYO is a great organization Founded in 1907 and rooted in our faith traditions of charity and justice, Catholic Charities supports families, aging adults and adults with disabilities, and youth through social services and opportunities for healthy growth and development.
cons: The case managers who work with the families the organization houses are barely being paid above the client subsidy amount.

pros: we’re committed to helping families and friends find the perfect vacation rental to create

pros: If you're ambitious there's great opportunity to jump in and grow by taking on new responsibilities (there is always more to be done). Organization appears to be shifting in positive directions, but change is slow.

review_title: Overall good place to work if you can handle a low salary

job_title: Counselor I in South Amboy, NJ

pros: Everyone was really friendly and super helpful, I didn't want to leave and would recommend working there to anyone.

review_title: A great Organization but disspointing the abuse of those in charge
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Walton Beach, FL

job_title: Case Manager in Fort Worth, TX
